newsitem.title: PERU: Peru hands back captured Ecuadorean soldiers.
newsitem.headline: Peru hands back captured Ecuadorean soldiers.

text.p: Peru's armed forces handed back to Ecuador on Thursday seven Ecuadorean soldiers captured after crossing a disputed border zone with high-tech arms and dozens of anti-personnel mines.
"At 8:15 a.m. (1315 GMT) the Ecuadorean soldiers were handed over to Ecuador," Capt. Juan Sanchez, of the Bagua military post in the border region, told Reuters.

The incident has inflamed tensions between the two Andean neighbours, who fought a bloody, month-long war at the border in 1995 and are negotiating in Brazil over a permanent solution to the decades-old dispute.
Peru claims the Ecuadorean soldiers violated its territory and were seeking to lay mines, but Quito sought to minimise the incident as an "accidental" incursion.
Gen. Paco Moncayo, head of Ecuador's joint chiefs of staff, admitted his soldiers may have strayed into Peruvian territory but denied they were laying mines.
The soldiers were handed over "in perfect health" to the head of the Ecuadorean military's representative on an international observer mission, Col. Jorge Brito, local Peruvian radio reported.

Peruvian troops said they caught one Ecuadorean sergeant, two corporals and four soldiers on Tuesday with a haul that included 60 anti-personnel mines, German-made guns, infra-red binoculars, five rocket and grenade launchers, maps of the territory and cameras.
Peru's acting Foreign Minister Jorge Gonzalez Izquierdo said he regretted the Ecuadorean incursion, but was confident the peace dialogue would stay on track.
Dozens of soldiers were killed and hundreds injured from both sides in the 1995 conflict, the latest in a series of armed flare-ups in recent decades.
